Title: Bioculture
Content: Bioculture is the combination of biological and cultural factors that affect human behavior. It is an area of study bounded by the medical sciences, landscape ecology, cultural anthropology and disability studies. Along these lines one can see the biosphere the earth as it is affected by the human as the adaptation of the natural to the human. Bioculture is characterized by the 21st centurys attitude toward the body. It assumes that in bioculture there is a diverse way to know the workings of the body and mind. It seeks to develop and encourage not only experts but also parts of peoples bodies and minds as the subject of study. BioCultura is a trademark registered in 1983 by the Asociación Vida Sana. alternative definition of the term bioculture is all the practical aspects of the use of living things in culture. It includes agriculture production of food and clothing forestry animal breeding and training the pet trade. Sana elaborated in 1981 the bases for the development of ecological agriculture in Spain through the booklets of norms. In 1983 he began to organize the BioCultura fair in Madrid with the Biocultura Foundation. Sana is the founder of the Institute of Ecology in Madrid. The aim was to offer an opportunity to the first organic producers to make their products known to consumers. They coined the term BioCultura from the prefix Bio joined to the word culture. The use and popularity of the brand has caused it to be used as a vocable to determine the sector of bio or eco culture. Bioculture ethics deals with how humans treat animals and plants. Ethics in Bioculture come into question especially in situations where the animals are in artificially created environments that are completely controlled by human. In such situations humans control not only the animals but also the plants. Plants and animals could be bred by humans to be later consumed or utilized by humans in some way. For example agricultural farming for food and clothing breeding raising and then slaughtering animals for food. forests to eventually cut them for wood or breeding animals and plants and experimenting on them. Humans decide how the life of the nonhuman organism will be led. Animals and plants could be bred for entertainment purposes also. For example developing plant nurseries to harvest flowers building and maintaining zoos aquariums for entertainment. breeding animals for sports like horse riding or bull fighting pet trade. Not all plants and animals raised in Bioculture are treated badly or are hurt. Some as in case of pet trade the pets are looked after The pet owner is considered to be responsible. nonhuman organism is bred with the end goal to benefit humans. Paul Taylor asks in his book on the fairness of hurting these animals and plants for our benefit or fun. Even when we dont have love and affection towards some stranger moral ethics require us to behave. for taking care of all things pertaining to the pet. The question then arises as to how this translate this ethical duty and responsibility to the field of Bioculture for plants and animals. Well with them well with them. The question is how do we apply this to the world of plants and animal?
